sub_title: Assistant Professor Regional Water and Climate Governance at Utrecht University
summary:
“Beyond: ‘space is scarce’ and ‘not everything is possible'" 

Many sustainability challenges come down to a lack of scarce space. The energy transition requires space; climate change adaptation requires space; sustainable agriculture requires space. At the same time, space is needed for housing, travelling and amenities. Henceforth, spatial sustainability challenges can easily become politicized. All of us, in our capacity as a citizen, policymaker, politician entrepreneur, parent and so forth will be affected by sustainability transformations, both those ongoing and those forthcoming, in the years and decades to come. How can we improve societal decision making in such a way that we maximize the solution space, but at the same time are enabled to reach fair and legitimate compromises once tough political choices are on the table? My research and teaching focus on two specific contributions to this wide-ranging issue:

-          citizen engagement in regional water- and climate governance
-          improved science-policy interactions through knowledge co-creation

projects.title: STAR-FLOOD
projects.description: STAR-FLOOD stands for: “STrengthening And Rede-signing European FLOOD risk practices: Towards appropriate and resilient flood risk governance arrangements”. This programme was recently awarded a grant of 5.4 Million Euros by the European Union (FP7). The project is focused on analysing, explaining, evaluating and designing policies to better deal with flood risks from rivers in urban agglomerations across Europe. The results of this ambitious programme are expected to be highly relevant for policies and law at the European, national and regional level and for the development of public-private partnerships. STAR-FLOOD runs from 1 October 2012 until 31 March 2016.

profile_positions.description: The Water, Climate and Future Deltas hub is a platform for scientists and external stakeholders to jointly work on ensuring the sustainability of our world’s deltas. At the hub, scientific experts from a broad range of disciplines cooperate directly with experts in the field to combine knowledge on natural system functioning with spatial planning, land and water governance and legislative frameworks. This allows for developing resilient delta management strategies, which is urgently needed to sustain the quality of life in these unique ecosystems.

profile_positions.description: TRANS-ADAPT focuses on bottom-up community based initiatives for flood risk management. The project focuses how the institutional conditions for realising such initiatives can be created as well as on identifying action perspectives for actors interested in realising such initiatives. Case studies in The Netherlands, Austria, Ireland and France will be analysed and evaluated and formative scenario analyses will be carried out together with actors involved in the case studies. My role is to coordinate Utrecht University's input in the project.
profile_positions.title: Principal Investigator at the TRANS-ADAPT project on bottom-up initiatives for flood risk management

profile_positions.description:
My PhD research dealt with transitions in wastewater infrastructures in several Western European countries. These wastewater infrastructures are often criticized for consuming too much water, treating wastewater in an inefficient way and for their failure to reuse and recycle water and nutrients. Furthermore, maintenance of infrastructures is often lagging behind and there are hormone and medicine residues present in the effluent of wastewater treatment plants. From a development perspective it is often argued that the ‘WC-sewage combination’ has become a desirable status symbol for developing countries, and for that reason hampers the development of ‘appropriate’ sanitary infrastructures for the poor. 
The sustainable transformation of wastewater infrastructures is often portrayed as a choice between centralized and decentralized systems. I aimed, however, to look beyond this dichotomy and looked for ‘modernized mixtures’, win-win situations between both extremes.

I carried out a comparative case study analysis of Dutch, German and Swedish pilot projects in which wastewater management technologies are experimented with in a domestic setting. Desk research, participatory observation and interviews with consumers and providers have been used to analyze innovation processes in various eco-villages and other new building areas.

My research showed that innovation in wastewater infrastructures is much focused on developing technologies for solving sustainability problems, but that many projects fail to address the question for which problems the new technologies form a solution, how the problems can best be understood and who should play what role in solving the problems. Furthermore, the life-world of the domestic end-user should more often form the starting point: the wishes and demands of end-users concerning convenience, hygiene, esthetics and status provide insight in the opportunities and pitfalls for successful innovation in sanitation.
